review_title: Assistente di Bachelor in formazione di master
job_title: Assistente Di Bachelor In Formazione Di Master in Lugano
pros:
- Projects that are interesting.
- Working while studying.
cons:
- Low salary.
- There is no a professional growing.

pros: Research-oriented career Useful to mix scholastic and work environments Experts help you grow professionally The work involves very different tasks
cons: The hours and amount of work, despite being the same contract for all students, vary greatly depending on who is the superior and in which lab you work.

review_title: Nice empolyer but old management style and with over-stress over results
pros:
- being a university of applied sciences, you do research but you get real working experience while still being in academic environment
- possibility to teach/tutor students
- nice locations, very close to nature and mountains
cons:
- depending on who's your supervisor, you may actually have 0 supervision because the people in the management area is too stressed and full of duties which cannot be performed by a single indivual
- depending on your team, you may get very stressed co-worker which sometimes won't even want to say hi back to you
- no food/mensa, no tea nor coffe nor anything
- some managers are cocky and tend to over-stress people
- many people in the past had bornouts and left with little or no advice because of bad management

review_title: Good Place To work and grow
cons: Some Repetitive tasks; Projects are not always stimulating

review_title: Postdoc Researcher at IDSIA (or as it is called here, Research Collaborator with a Ph.D.)
pros:
* You get to work with some of the top ranked experts in the fields of Theoretical Computer Science and/or Machine Learning.
* The payment is almost higher than any other postdoc position you can find.
* Teaching is usually not mandatory, but an option.
* You get to work and live in a beautiful and vibrant place.
cons:
* There are not many teaching opportunities, which is a downside if you plan to go to academia and need some research experience.
* For non-EU members, there is always the hassle of getting Swiss work permit, which eventually comes true, but sometimes has long delays.

pros: Good salary, flexibility in working hours, interesting projects to work on. Employees are generally competent in their subjects and there is the possibility of learning a lot of things
cons: It is difficult to get a permanent positions, there are no real bonuses (but this is ok since it's an university).

pros:
It's academia so you work a lot -- At the frontiers of science
Industrial partnerships are more common in Switzerland than in other countries (helps for funding + it's good to really apply science sometimes)
Lugano and the whole Ticino region is one of the best place on Earth (not kidding)
cons: It's academia so you work a lot -- And a lot is sometimes too much

pros: It is one of the few workplace in Tessin for highly educated engineer, but this is the only positive thing about SUPSI.
cons: Low salaries, temporary contracts, no benefits, very stressfull workplace. Indeed the turnover is very high.

pros: There is a friendly environment with lots of projects with the industries.
cons: From the academic point of view there is a lack of facilities and scientific background.

review_title: I am currently a PhD Student at Supsi
pros: Flexible Working Model, good freedom of conducting your own research
cons: Little interest in doing academic research

pros: Good working environment, interesting projects, high quality of infrastructure and laboratories
Very interesting projects, large field of reasearch, very good work environment.
